Cabernet Sauvignon Peconic Bay Vineyards, Cutchogue, 1994. About $18.

The many fans of Peconic Bay's fairly simple, direct style are likely to find the owner Ray Blum's latest cabernet pleasing, especially when the stiff tannins soften up. A wellspring of fruitiness lurks, waiting to be freed up by the passage of time, in this virtually opaque ruby-colored drink.

The woody scrim, from the American-oak barrels in which the wine matured for 14 months, dominates everything, but should soften. For now, the concentrated grapey black-currant flavor (the wine is 15 percent merlot) just about passes through the tannins and into the smooth texture.

The roughness can be immediately eased if, as Mr. Blum recommends on the back label, you match the wine with pasta or ''heartier cuisine.'' I took his advice Monday night -- spaghetti and baked eggplant -- and it worked.

Quite often, newly released wines are hard to read, and by the time they are ready, they are difficult to find for a rereading. This is likely to prove true with the 1994 cabernet, because Peconic Bay made only 320 cases of it.
